questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermographism The given clinical picture shows Dermographism.

Highyeild:

Dermographism Dermo = skin, Graphism = to write. aka urticaria factitia It is an exaggerated wheal and flare response that occurs within minutes of the skin being stroked or scratched. It is the most common subtype among the physical urticarias. Cause: Skin trauma releases antigens that react with membrane-bound IgE on mast cells that trigger the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators. Features: Symptomatic dermographism is characterized by itching or burning skin sensations and the development of pruritic wheals and flares in areas exposed to shearing forces on the skin. The shape of wheals and erythema is mostly linear or consists of linear elements because of the forms of eliciting stimuli.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Dermatoglyphics: Study of patterns or skin markings on fingers, hands, and feet, and its application in criminology Option C. Pathergy: Skin condition in that minor skin trauma can lead to ulcers which are resistant to healing Option D. Angioedema: Abrupt localised swelling of the deep dermis and Subcutaneous layer, usually affecting eyelids and lips.

Extraedge:

Types of Dermographism: Type of dermographism Seen in Feature White dermographism Atopic Eczema Occurs due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking of the skin Cholinergic dermographism Cholinergic urticaria A type of dermographism that occurs in response to an increase in body temperature, such as during exercise or exposure to heat. The skin becomes raised and itchy, and small red bumps may appear. Symptomatic dermographism Physical urticaria Characterised by itching or burning skin sensations and the development of pruritic wheals and flare in areas exposed to shearing forces on the skin. Black dermographism Discolouration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object

questions.text: A patient gets recurrent urticaria while doing exercise and on exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholinergic urticaria Physical urticarias come with hives on exposure toward typical physical agents. In cholinergic urticaria, it gets triggered by sweating. In the present question, exercise and exposure to sunlight both induce sweat and hence the answer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Op tion A- chronic idiopathic urticaria will not have physical factors associated with it. Option B- dermographism is a type of physical urticaria with linear wheals after trauma. Option D- photodermatitis will have itching and redness after sun exposure

questions.text: A 5 year old child comes with pigmented tan to brown coloured lesions on trunk as shown below. Occasional symptoms of itching bother the child. The parents bring the child you do the following first bed side test to reach to a conclusion:

options.label: C
options.text: Scratching the lesions with a blunt object

questions.correct_answer: C. Scratching the lesions with a blunt object
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scratching the lesions with a blunt object Child having brown lesions which are itchy points to a diagnosis of urticaria pigmentosa. It shows small tan to brown macules or papules distributed mostly on the trunk and classically spares the central face, palms, and soles. Darier’s sign is the formation of a wheal upon stroking or rubbing skin lesions and suggests the diagnosis of cutaneous mastocytosis. The wheal forms due to the release of mast cell mediators after stroking the lesion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Diascopy would be the process of pressing the lesions with glass slide. It is positive in lupus vulgaris where it shows apple jelly nodules. It is not useful in the present case. Option B- Wood’s lamp would not help in the diagnosis of mastocytosis. It is useful in other conditions like vitiligo, tinea, scabies, ash-leaf macule, erythrasma. Option D- KOH mount is done in fungal infections like tinea, pityriasis versicolor, whiff test in bacterial vaginosis, scabies mite demonstration.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency with the complaint of breathlessness and below rashes on her body which were extremely itchy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spontaneous urticaria The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Spontaneous Urticaria. It is characterized by Evanescence, and pink edema which are very itchy and heals without pigmentation.

Highyeild:

URTICARIA (HIVES ) It is a vascular reaction of the skin characterized by the appearance of wheals, generally surrounded by a red halo or flare and associated with severe itching, stinging, or pricking sensations. Pathogenesis: Mast cell degranulation is triggered by immune (IgE mediated) and non-immune (cytokines, complement) mechanisms leading to the release of histamine which causes vasodilation. Features:- Wheals: caused by localized edema. Clearing of the central region may occur, and lesions may coalesce, producing an annular or polycyclic pattern. Subcutaneous swellings (angioedema) may or may not accompany the wheals. Site: Anywhere in the body

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Acute atopic dermatitis: It is a condition that causes dry, itchy, and inflamed skin. It's common in young children but can occur at any age. Option C . Fixed drug eruption: It is characterized by a well-defined erythematous patch, plaque, or bullous eruption that recurs at the same site as the result of systemic exposure to a causative drug Option D . Allergic contact dermatitis: It refers to a group of skin disorders in which the skin reaction is due to direct contact with the causative agent characterised by surface skin changes such as blistering, dryness, peeling, and redness.

questions.text: In your dermatology viva on Mast cell disorder, the professor asks you about the mast cell. What among the following is not true regarding mast cells?

options.label: A
options.text: C-Kit is the marker of mast cell

options.label: B
options.text: Serves as the first line of defense

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only found in skin Mast cells occur in most tissues, but are particularly numerous in the skin, bronchus, nasal mucosa, and gut.

Highyeild:

Mast cells Mast cells were first described by Ehrlich in 1877, who distinguished them from other connective tissue cells by their ability to stain metachromatically with basic aniline dyes. They are larger than eosinophils and basophils They occur in most tissues but are particularly numerous in the skin, bronchus, nasal mucosa, and gut. In the skin , mast cells are distributed close to blood vessels, nerves and appendages, and are most numerous in the subpapillary dermis, in the region of the superficial dermal vascular plexus. C-kitt (CD117) is a marker of mast cell

Random:

Explanation of Other Options: Option A . C-Kit is the marker of mast cell: This is true. C-Kit (CD117) is a well-established marker for identifying mast cells. Option B . Serves as the first line of defense: This is also true. Mast cells are strategically located in tissues where they can encounter pathogens or allergens first, making them important players in the initial immune response. Option D . Release histamine: This is another true statement. Histamine is a key mediator released by mast cells during allergic reactions and inflammatory processes.

questions.text: Following is a type of physical urticaria:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermographism Dermatographism, also known as dermographism urticaria is an urticarial eruption upon pressure or trauma to the skin. The literal meaning is "to write on the skin." Downward pressure on the skin produces a linear wheal in the shape of the applied external force.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- Urticaria pigmentosa is a type of cutaneous mastocytosis presenting as pigmented patches on the trunk in children. When rubbed these lesions form wheals (darier sign) Option C- Urticarial vasculitis is a small vessel vasculitis presenting as urticaria like lesions Option D- Auto-immune urticaria is not a physical urticaria but an autoimmune damage to mast cells.

questions.text: An atopic patient presents with lesions as shown. The lesions are transient and warm. The lesions are found to be histiamine related. The lesions can be described as all except
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vasoconstriction Wheals of urticaria due to histamine release are edematous, red, and itchy. Vasodilation is seen, not vasoconstriction. Urticaria is more common in atopy.

questions.text: A mother brought her 1-year-old baby girl with hyperpigmented macules over the trunk. The physician elicited Darier's sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urticaria pigmentosa The given clinical scenario with hyperpigmented macules and Darier’s sign is suggestive of Urticaria Pigmentosa.

Highyeild:

Urticaria Pigmentosa Aka Cutaneous Mastocytosis Age: Common in children Cause: It is due to abnormal collections of mast cells in the skin. Histopathology: Metachromatic granules on toluidine blue stain Marker: CD 117 Features: Brown patches and freckles Darier sign: When a lesion of cutaneous Mastocytosis is stroked, histamine is released leading to erythema with urticarial halo The skin becomes swollen, itchy, and red: A result of compression of mast cells, which are hyperactive in these diseases Treatment: Antihistamines Ketotifen

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Xeroderma pigmentosa: It is an autosomal recessive genodermatosis that results due to mutations in nucleotide excision repair characterised by severe photosensitivity, skin pigmentary changes, malignant tumor development, and occasionally progressive neurologic degeneration Option C. Herpes zoster: Aka Shingles. It is a localised, blistering, and painful rash caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus. Option D. Glucagonoma: It is a rare tumor of the pancreatic alpha cells that results in the overproduction of the hormone, glucagon characterized by Dermatosis, Diabetes, Deep vein thrombosis, and Depression.
